Rezensionen
must suffice to show that the chronological background for the lists of Kasens,  etc.  is by no means finally and accurately established^. 
It must be regretfully admitted that this is not the only direction in which the author's competence in matters of epigraphy invites criticism.  Both in the handling and in the interpretation of texts we find occasional dogmatic assertions quite unsupported by the evidence which she quotes.  For example,  in her treatment of IG,  V.  i,  258,  on p.  106,  where the first half of a pentameter can only be read as Teioafxevibi - T^iy - she states that epigraphical,  metrical and historical considerations combine to favour the restoration of the second word as the name' / d / zcot.  But the partly preserved letter is not,  and cannot have been,  alpha^ as was pointed out when the stone was first published { BSA.  xiii.  p.  196,  63 ; cf.  the facsimile.  Art.  Orth.  p.  301,  No.  10 ),  and there is no trace of an iota or any other letter before the sigma.  And further,  the appeal to metrical grounds does not help,  seeing that we ( inà4afxid ( bv ending a pentameter in IG.  V.  i,  599 ( quoted,  but without comment,  by Miss Chrimes,  /.  c.  note 2 ).  In the circumstances the appeal to Herod,  ix.  35f.  to show that Tisamenos and lamos were brothers on this stone seems a waste of ingenuity.  No less misleading is the statement on p.  128 ( n.  i ) where the remains of a letter in Art.  Orth.  Ho.  11,  I.  4 are said to seem more likely to ht gamma^ though in that publication it is definitely described as having been round ; thus her restoration €y [ xvva ] yérai cannot possibly be justified.  No less arbitrary is the treatment of IG.  V.  I,  824 ( p.  484,  and note 8 ) where the name restored by Kolbe as * yQtii\y' ] al\a\ is read as ^YQfxivla with the comment that the letters vi appear to be ligatured.  There is no trace on the facsimile of a possible ligature,  which would in any case be a surprising feature in an early sixth century inscription.  Again Tib.  Claudius Atticus son of Herodes { IG.  V,  i 45 ) is not to be ( and could not be ) identified with the Sophist ( p.  444,  No.  20 ),  but must be his son,  as is usually and rightly assumed. 
As a last example of the dangers of wishful thinking we may note the treatment of IG.  V.  i,  1346 ( »ex meridionali Peloponnesi plaga in museum Nanianum allatum«,  Boeckh,  GIG.  1393,  but now lost ).  The author's attribution of this stone to Sparta ( p.  342f.  ) is open to several objections.  In II.  I—4 which runs thus : * H ieqà \yeQOv\aia Г.  'loijhov ^Enafpqoôeixov àyQerevaavxa го god 'ëroç it should be observed ( i ) that we have no other instance of a Hiera Gerousia at Sparta^,  ( 2 ) that there is no precise epigraphi -
4.  Some improvements in the list of Patronomoi were published by the reviewer,  BS A.  xliii.  ( 1948 ) pp.  2i4ff. ,  whilst this book was in the press ; e.  g.  Kleon ( dated by Miss C.  to c.  122 / 3 ) is to be moved to 147 / 8. 
5.  This inscription is not mentioned by J.  H.  Oliver in his study of The Hiera Gerousia ( Hespena,  Suppl.  vi.  1941 ),  who thinks that the institution first reached mainland Greece,  at Athens,  c.  176 / 7 A.  D.
